I don't quite see how the umbrella as a phallic symbol in this story. Suzy has always felt that Grace and her family had abandoned her, and now, as she is alone facing the rain and the indifferent world, her only protection is the stranger’s umbrella, therefore Suzy suggests the umbrella as a ‘weapon’. She is used to deal with her problems without asking help from her family, or sometimes, she would seek help from men like Damian, Michael,or Caleb. Being a loner in this world, the umbrella is her only shield and self-defense weapon. Therefore, Suzy feels safer after she took the umbrella, and ‘she can leave now, out into the torrential sea where her parents wait’.

Just wanted to know if there were any reactions to my reading of the umbrella passage. Remember, it's Freud, not me, who says that umbrellas are phallic symbols! (bet you never thought of this, did you?) Anyways, to recapitulate. Freud says umbrellas are phalli, and that broken umbrellas are castrated phalli. Suzy remembers that she has left her umbrella on the train...And when Bob makes the racist mistake of identifying her with Grace, she asks whether she left an umbrella there the other day. Bob then lets her rummage through the bin where lost umbrellas are kept, and she chooses one, and this becomes "a weapon." Two points. First, if umbrellas are phalli, then they imply a connection with the girls' father and, by extension, Korea. A lost or broken umbrella suggests a broken connection to family and to tradition. Second, Suzy takes the "all Asian girls look alike" racist assumption of Bob and uses it as "a weapon." If the broken umbrella suggests a lost tradition and the emasculation of Asian authority, then Suzy's appropriation of an anonymous umbrella and her use of it as a weapon is an affirmation of her identity. BH

I thought it was interesting how Raymond feels uncomfortable discussing race politics with Betty, even though he did it constantly with Aurora. With Aurora, it seemed that he felt 'more Asian' than her, and therefore she needed to be taught how to become more Asian. (It's also interesting how Raymond doesn't seem to take into consideration that Aurora is also half-Irish, as if that side of her ethnicity is irrelevant or unimportant because it is 'white.') But with Betty, I think Raymond realizes that she has more 'ethnic clout' than him, since she herself immigrated from Vietnam, whereas Raymond is a second generation Chinese. And when Betty describes Aurora and Raymond as living in the same world, I think Raymond becomes aware of the flexibility and subjectivity of ethnic identity. Whereas before he viewed ethinicity in terms of either you're Asian or you're white, he now comes to realize that other factors contribute to identity formation as well, such as where you grew up and what sorts of experiences you've had. (Ie. Fighting in the war is not the same as living through the war.) This was my favorite section in the book because I felt that Raymond was humbled by Betty being 'more Asian' than him, and I think this was a factor in his abandonment of critiquing Aurora.

Hey all, I just wanted to post a copy of an excellent 2nd paper for those who would like to see one. It's a good example of the depth of analysis and close attention to the text that we're looking for. john The Lost Swimmer’s Beacon Suzy and Grace Park, the two sisters of Suki Kim’s semiautobiographical narrative The Interpreter, seemed to be coexisting distantly with parents in a country that was as foreign to them as the concepts of family and home. Suzy, whose perspective was presented in the novel, never quite felt entirely Korean or American. She was always perceived as the “other” by others and by herself. "The pastel house by the shore. The sunlit faces of her parents." Suzy secretly coveted what other, seemingly assimilated Americans had, like her college roommate with Jen and her family’s East Coast home. Words such as “pastel” and “sunlit” suggest beautiful, picturesque scenes and radiant, smiling faces. Suzy observed none of that growing up, in a “house” that was always moving and parents who were always troubled. "Not guilty, never guilty, never having crossed the line between what is family and what is not, what is right and what is deadly wrong, what is Korea and what is not home." The line, while being one defining other and same, encompassed all the turbulent aspects of Suzy’s broken life. Her family was distant, her family was doing things that were “deadly wrong” in the eyes of the Korean community, and neither Korea nor America ever felt like home. One was the source of the Park sisters’ otherness, and one was the geographical location in which they struggled to belong. "The line was always there. The line had been marked from the beginning, tightly woven around the two girls who couldn’t find their way no matter how hard they tried." The “line” between who belonged and who was “other” was a vague, vexing construction that always made Suzy the other woman, the other race, and the other daughter. It was woven around her so tightly that she could never extricate herself from the status quo; she continued to be haunted and made restless by her otherness. Grace took a different approach to life and still never managed to find her way by overcoming the otherness that was manifest in her dual personalities. She was involved in her parents’ treacherous affairs yet was simultaneously always rebelling. "...unless their parents went away, unless their parents sailed a boat never to return, unless their parents drove to work one morning and never came back… " Suzy’s quest for closure of the murder of her parents drove her to learn more about herself, about her family, and about her sister. She discovered motives behind her parents’ distance, motives behind Grace’s deliberate alienation from her, and motives behind her constant searching. The murder of her parents was the catalyst that initiated Suzy’s search for herself, and the murder of her parents forced her to look beyond constructs such as the line separating other from same. "At the end will be the lighthouse. At the end will be a new country. She could swim through any waters." Lighthouses exist as beacons to wandering ships, just as Suzy’s parents, their ashes scattered by the Montauk lighthouse, existed as beacons to focus Suzy’s misguided pursuits. Nobody was ever able to tell Suzy what she wanted, not even herself, but after she spent enough time searching for the clues to her parents’ tragic disappearance, she ended up finding explanations of things which defined herself. Solving her own life’s mystery and learning about who she was instilled Suzy with a new sense of family, new self-awareness, and new confidence to “swim through any waters.” Thanks to Morgan for sharing this.

Hey guys. I was just thinking about the article by J. Chan (Contemporary Asian American Men's Issues). The plight of Asian American men reminded me of something that I learned about in a Women's Studies class: the plight of African American women. African American women feminists were misunderstood by white feminists because of cultural and racial differences. But they felt they were also being oppressed by African American men in the struggle for civil rights because of patriarchal structures. The same thing appears to be happening with Asian American men. They are excluded from patriarchy because of certain stereotypes that depict them as passive. But they also seem to have issues with Asian American women, who they believe might be selling out or propagating certain stereotypes. This separates them from the two groups they would seem to have the most solidarity with (males and Asians). I thought this was really interesting because I never thought of males as being oppressed before...so I can kind of understand where Frank Chin's anger comes from....

BH Linda Ngov Huang/ Gamber Asian American Studies 5 06/28/04 Is Everyone Ethnic? If ethnicity is nothing but a term used to differentiate people, is the body also a basis of differentiation? If so, then Werner Sollors’ thesis that everyone is ethnic becomes problematic. The reason being is that according to Franz Fanon’s essay, “The Fact of Blackness,” the body, particularly the black body, is the site of alienation. Hence, if the body is indeed an ethnic factor, then the usage of ethnicity has negative connotations. In other words, when looking at the term ethnicity, one cannot ignore that it means to describe the “Other.” However, because Sollors asserts in “Who is Ethnic,” that ethnicity is a universalist term that includes dominant groups, he underemphasizes the negativity that is associated in the usage of ethnicity. To Sollors’ credit, his investigation on the historiography of ethnicity does highlight how ethnicity is often used to mean “nonstandard.” He mentions that even by the mid-nineteenth century, when ethnicity was finally defined as a person’s particular race or nation, the word was still only used to point out a person’s difference to the dominant group (Reader, 130). With the acknowledgement that use of ethnicity often coincides with discrimination, race, manifested by the body, must be included as an ethnic factor. Fanon explains the experience of being trapped in a body that is racialized. He states, “In the white world the man of color encounters difficulties in the development of his bodily schema…A slow composition of my self as a body in the middle of a spatial and temporal world—such seems to be the schema. It does not impose itself on me; it is, rather, a definitive structuring of the self and of the world-definitive because it creates a real dialectic between my body and the world…” (Reader, 95). Ethnicity is the dialogue that differentiates the “Other” from the dominant and the racial body is the feature that places a person into the category of the “Other.” Since the colored body is registered as different to the white world, race, as an aspect of ethnicity, is negatively viewed. The understanding that ethnicity has negative connotations is lost though when Sollors argues that dominant groups are also ethnic. One reason that he gives for his argument is that ethnic studies have emerged from the Afro-American Civil Rights Movement and that “an omission of the Afro-American tradition in a discussion of ethnic culture in America would create a serious gap in our reflections” (Reader, 131). This statement is problematic because as we have learned from Fanon, African-Americans are not part of the dominant culture. In fact, their colored bodies make them ethnic because they are different from the preferred majority (whites). By absorbing African-Americans into the dominant group, Sollors removes the injury that comes from being ethnic.
